Parents: We are excited about the start of school tomorrow. Please be patient if you are dropping off your child, we anticipate a higher than normal traffic pattern this year. Staff will be present to help direct cars.

Also, please remember that we are asking for you to assist in screening your children before they come to school each day. Our staff is also screening themselves. If you child displays any of the following symptoms that cannot be otherwise explained, please keep your child home and contact the school immediately:

Fever of 100.4 F or greater
Sore Throat
Cough (New onset/uncontrolled)
Diarrhea, Vomiting or Abdominal Pain
Headache (New Severe Onset, especially with fever)
New Loss of Taste of Smell
Muscle or Body Aches or Fatigue
Congestion or Runny Nose
Shortness of Breath or Difficulty Breathing

I have attached several charts for guidance during this new (hopefully temporary) normal. We appreciate your support as we work to start our new school year and keep it as safe and normal as possible.

And Just Like That!!!! Things are changing!! Governor Holcomb just announced a State Wide mask mandate for all individuals ages 8 in above when out in public spaces and facilities. Yes, this includes school buildings.

We are waiting for the released mandate language before moving forward, however, we are preparing to purchase and provide 5 washable mask for all students in grades 3 - 12. While the mandate states children 8 and above, we will also make purchases for students in Pre-K through 2nd grade should the parent desire to have their children wear them.

These mask are color coded and in a washable mesh carrying pouch. We are discussing how to handle the washing of the mask and distribution.

While I know this is upsetting to many, we will come together as a school community to make the best of this situation. I will keep you updated when we get the final mandate language and also updated regarding the washable mask.

We appreciate all of you more than you know! We need you now more than ever supporting Hamilton Schools! We are Marine Strong!

Tony Cassel, Superintendent

Job Posting: Community Library Assistant @ Hamilton Community Schools.

Pay: $12.00 per hour.
Must be 21+ years of age

Hamilton Community Schools is looking for a friendly and organized individual who is interested in working at Hamilton Community Schools in our Library 1 evening a week and 1 Saturday a month during the school year.

We are gearing up and reorganizing our library to open it to the public on Thursday evenings from 5:00 p.m. - 8:00 p.m. and 1 Saturday a month from 9:00 a.m. - 12:00 p.m. during the school year. The library will be closed during school holiday breaks.

Responsibilities would include assisting community members with library needs, shelving books, and other library responsibilities as determined by the librarian and head librarian aide.

If interested, please send a letter of interest/resume to Anthony Cassel @ anthony.cassel@hcs.k12.in.us.

On February 9, 2019, 184 students representing thirteen area high schools and IMPACT Institute traveled to various locations in Northeast Indiana to compete in the Regional SkillsUSA competition. Of the 184 Impact students that competed, 94 placed in the top five in their competition as an individual or as a team and will advance to the Indiana SkillsUSA State Competition on April 19th and 20th, 2019, in Indianapolis.

The following students from Hamilton placed in the Regional Competition: Ethan Makris - Digital Cinema Production, Taylor Stickan - 3-D Visualization and Animation, and Joey Zarate - Photography. Good Luck at State!!!

Great things are happening at Hamilton Schools! It's a great day to be a Marine!
